question: Question_03_(b)
sols:
Again using the Disc Method, this time we are rotating around the
y-axis. Because \emph{A} runs along the y-axis, this means that the
inner radius of the disc will be 0. The outer radius of the disc will be
given by first the line \emph{x = y}, and then by the circle, which,
when solved for \emph{x} is given by $x = \sqrt{1 - y^2}$. The first
radius, \emph{x = y} will apply from \emph{y = 0} until the intersection
point of the line and the circle. The second radius,
$x = \sqrt{1 - y^2}$ will apply from the intersection point to \emph{y =
1}.

To find the intersection point of the line and circle, we use the same
process as the previous question, setting the two equations equal to
each other and solving for \emph{y}. In this case, the intersection
point will be at $y = \frac1{\sqrt{2}}$.

We now have all the pieces we need to set up the integral and solve, as
follows.

\begin{align*}
  V &= \int_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \pi y^2 dy + \int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}^1 \pi \left(\sqrt{1-y^2}\right)^2 \,dy \\
  &= \int_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \pi y^2 dy + \pi \int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}^1 1-y^2 \,dy \\
  &= \pi \left[\frac{y^3}{3}\right|_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} + \pi \left[y-\frac{y^3}{3}\right|_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}^1 \\
  &= \pi \left[\frac{\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^3}{3}\right] + \pi \left[1-\frac{1^3}{3}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\frac{\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\right)^3}{3}\right] \\
  &= \frac{\pi}{6\sqrt{2}} + \pi \left[\frac{3}{3}-\frac{1}{3}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}+\frac{1}{6\sqrt{2}}\right] \\
  &= \frac{\pi}{6\sqrt{2}} + \pi \left[\frac{6\sqrt{2}-2\sqrt{2}-6+1}{6\sqrt{2}}\right] \\
  &= \pi\left[\frac{1}{6\sqrt{2}} + \frac{4\sqrt{2}-5}{6\sqrt{2}}\right] \\
  &= 2\pi\left[\frac{\sqrt{2}-1}{3\sqrt{2}}\right] \\
  &= \pi\left[\frac{2-\sqrt{2}}{3}\right]\end{align*}

We can use the shell method to calculate the volume of this solid of
revolution as well. If you don't know the shell method, don't worry
about understanding this solution. Since we are using the shell method,
we should integrate in the x-variable. The integral should be of the
form

\begin{align*}
2 \pi \int_a^b x (f(x) - g(x)) dx\end{align*}

where a is the smallest x-value in the region (which will be zero), b is
the largest x-value in the region (which was calculated in
\href{http://wiki.ubc.ca/Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH103/April_2012/Question_3_\%28a\%29}{Problem
3a} to be $\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$), f(x) is the largest y-value in the
region at x (which will correspond to the top of each cylindrical
shell), and g(x) is the smallest y-value in the region at x (which will
correspond to the bottom of each cylindrical shell). So the volume is

\begin{align*}
&2 \pi \int_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} [x  ( \sqrt{1-x^2} - x)] dx \\
&= 2 \pi \int_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} [x \sqrt{1 - x^2}] dx - 2 \pi \int_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} [x^2] dx\end{align*} We now use a u-substitution u= 1 - x\^{}2 in the first
integral, and evaluate the second integral directly.

\begin{align*}
&=  \pi \int_{\frac{1}{2}}^1 [\sqrt{u}] du - 2 \pi \frac{1}{3 \sqrt{2}^3} \\
&= \frac{2\pi}{3} \left[u^{3/2}\right]_{\frac{1}{2}}^1 - \frac{2 \pi}{6 \sqrt{2}} \\
&= \frac{2 \pi}{3} - \frac{2 \pi}{3 \sqrt{2}^3} - \frac{2 \pi}{6 \sqrt{2}} \\
&= \frac{2 \pi}{3} - \frac{2 \pi}{3 \sqrt{2}} \\
&= \pi \left[ \frac{2 - \sqrt{2}}{3} \right].\end{align*}
hints:
This problem can be done using either the disc method or the shell
method. If you want to use the disc method, since we're rotating around
the y-axis, we should be integrating in the y-variable.

The integral should be of the form

\begin{align*}
\pi \int_a^b [g(y)^2 - f(y)^2] dy \end{align*} where a is the smallest y-value in the region, b is the
largest y-value in the region, g(y) is the largest x-value in the region
at y, and f(y) is the smallest y-value in the region at y. Note that
here, a is 0, b is 1, and f(y) = 0. g(y) is a piecewise function. Let p
be the y-value of the point where the circle $x^2 + y^2  = 1$ and the
line $x = y$ intersect. Then from 0 to p, g(y) is given by y, and from p
to 1, g(y) is given by $\sqrt{1 - x^2}$. So try to find p and evaluate
the integral.
